Title: Brain Training Games Enhance Cognitive Function in Healthy Subjects
Citation: Al-Thaqib, A., Al-Sultan, F., Al-Zahrani, A., Al-Kahtani, F., Al-Regaiey, K., Iqbal, M., & Bashir, S. (2018). Brain training games enhance cognitive function in healthy subjects. Medical Science Monitor Basic Research, 24, 63-69. https://doi.org/10.12659/MSMBR.909022
Control_Group_Description: No training
Intervention_Description: Computerized cognitive training using Lumosity brain training application with games targeting flexibility, memory, attention, speed, and problem solving
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Lumosity games: Speed Match, Memory Matrix, Rotation Matrix, Face Memory, Money Comb, and Lost In Migration
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Non-blinded intervention with potential for performance bias; Complete outcome data with exclusion of non-compliant participants before analysis; Outcome assessors were blinded; No pre-registration but all expected outcomes reported

Title: Effects of Aerobic Exercise Training, Age, and Physical Fitness on Memory-Search Performance
Citation: Blumenthal, J. A., & Madden, D. J. (1988). Effects of aerobic exercise training, age, and physical fitness on memory-search performance. Psychology and Aging, 3(3), 280-285.
Variable_Name: mean reaction time (yes-response category; for memory-set size = 6)
Control_Group_Description: Anaerobic exercise (strength training) group that performed stretching exercises and weight training for 30-45 minutes, 2-3 times weekly for 12 weeks
Intervention_Description: Aerobic exercise consisting of 10 minutes of stretching followed by 30-45 minutes of continuous walking or jogging (approximately 3 miles) at 70-85% of maximal heart rate
Physical_Activity_Description: Walking/jogging at 70-85% of maximal heart rate
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; No evidence of deviations from intended interventions with 95% adherence reported; No missing outcome data reported (all 28 participants completed); Outcome measurement was computerized and objective; No pre-registration but all expected outcomes reported.
Intervention_Adherence: maintained heart rate in prescribed range 95% of time
Notes_From_File: the active control group was given anaerobic exericse, but it is clear from the description that this is equivalent to the "stretching" conditions used by other articles... so it was not the case that the control group received a correspondingly intense anaeorobic exerciseintervention; for the memory tests, I only used the data for memory-set size = 6. (there was also set sizes 2 and 4). In this study it was clear from the introduction that that they expected the set size of 2 to be a sort of negative contorl that they didn't expect to be sufficientlycognitively demaniding to distinguish a bona fide effect of the exercise intervention.; I did not include any of the regression rsults from Tabl2 4 because this was based on a theoretical model such that the results (slope, intercept) would have been different if there was a different model applied.; I only analyzed the 'Response type: Yes' because the

Title: Baduanjin Mind-Body Intervention Improves the Executive Control Function
Citation: Chen, T., Yue, G. H., Tian, Y., & Jiang, C. (2017). Baduanjin Mind-Body Intervention Improves the Executive Control Function. Frontiers in Psychology, 7, 2015. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2016.02015
Control_Group_Description: Progressive muscle relaxation training
Intervention_Description: Baduanjin mind-body exercise consisting of eight movements for limbs, body-trunk, and eye movements
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Mental focus, attention, and self-regulation during exercise
Physical_Activity_Description: Eight movements for limbs, body-trunk, and eye movements
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; No missing outcome data reported; No evidence of deviations from intended interventions; Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded; No pre-registration mentioned but expected outcomes reported; No selective reporting evident but no pre-registered protocol available.
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Baduanjin combines physical movements with breathing control and mental focus
Notes_From_File: This is a situation where the author's are CLAIMING that the intervention was cognitive, so I am required by my rules to describe it as both physical and cogntive
Variance_Conversion_Notes: Control PRE: Converted from SEM=6.060000, N=21; Control POST: Converted from SEM=6.490000, N=21; Intervention PRE: Converted from SEM=6.050000, N=21; Intervention POST: Converted from SEM=3.890000, N=21

Title: Adaptive n-back training does not improve fluid intelligence at the construct level: Gains on individual tests suggest that training may enhance visuospatial processing
Citation: Colom, R., Román, F. J., Abad, F. J., Shih, P. C., Privado, J., Froufe, M., Escorial, S., Martínez, K., Burgaleta, M., Quiroga, M. A., Karama, S., Haier, R. J., Thompson, P. M., & Jaeggi, S. M. (2013). Adaptive n-back training does not improve fluid intelligence at the construct level: Gains on individual tests suggest that training may enhance visuospatial processing. Intelligence, 41(5), 712-727. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.intell.2013.09.002
Control_Group_Description: No-contact control group that continued normal university student life
Intervention_Description: Adaptive n-back training program including visual, auditory, and dual versions. Training began with 4 sessions of visual adaptive n-back, followed by 4 sessions of auditory adaptive n-back, and then 16 sessions of adaptive n-back dual program.
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Adaptive n-back task requiring participants to remember stimuli presented n positions back in a sequence. Difficulty level (n) increased adaptively based on performance.
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but specific method not described. No missing outcome data (0% attrition). Intervention was delivered as intended with strict supervision. Outcome assessors likely not blinded to group allocation. No pre-registered protocol mentioned but all expected outcomes were reported.
Notes_From_File: SENSITIVITY: Some of the participants were under 18; I pooled the participants age means and SDs; when extracting values, I used the IRT-mean and IRT-SD when available because the authors realized retroactively that the random allocation of questions left one group with harder questions (these IRT values are hence more fair).;
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: SENSITIVITY: Some of the participants were under 18;; when extracting values, I used the IRT-mean and IRT-SD when available because the authors realized retroactively that the random allocation of questions left one group with harder questions (these IRT values are hence more fair).

Title: Effects of self-paced interval and continuous training on health markers in women
Citation: Connolly, L. J., Bailey, S. J., Krustrup, P., Fulford, J., Smietanka, C., & Jones, A. M. (2017). Effects of self-paced interval and continuous training on health markers in women. European Journal of Applied Physiology, 117(11), 2281-2293. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00421-017-3715-9
Recruitment_Method: Advertisements in local community venues and the University of Exeter news bulletin
Control_Group_Description: Continuation of inactive lifestyle
Intervention_Description: Self-paced cycling protocol with repeated 1-min exercise bouts comprising 30s low-intensity (~30% max effort), 20s moderate-intensity (~50-60% max effort), and 10s high-intensity (>90% max effort) cycling. 5 x 5-min blocks with 2-min passive recovery between blocks.
Physical_Activity_Description: Self-paced cycling with varying intensities
Activity_Presentation: Indoor cycling on Monark 894E cycle ergometer
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Adherence to intervention was high with supervised sessions; Low attrition (1 participant per group); Blinding of outcome assessors not mentioned; No pre-registered protocol available but expected outcomes reported.
Notes_From_File: Intervention adherence was estimated from the claim that the experimental groups completed an average of 35 out of 36 total sessions.; It is not stated directly in the article, but based on other HIIT studies it is clear that the target HRpeak was 80.

Title: Neural and Behavioral Effects of an Adaptive Online Verbal Working Memory Training in Healthy Middle-Aged Adults
Citation: Emch, M., Ripp, I., Wu, Q., Yakushev, I., & Koch, K. (2019). Neural and Behavioral Effects of an Adaptive Online Verbal Working Memory Training in Healthy Middle-Aged Adults. Frontiers in Aging Neuroscience, 11, 300. https://doi.org/10.3389/fnagi.2019.00300
Control_Group_Description: Low-level verbal working memory training (fixed 1-back level)
Intervention_Description: Adaptive online verbal n-back training where level increased/decreased based on performance. Started at 1-back level and could increase to maximum 9-back level.
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Verbal n-back task with letters presented sequentially. Participants pressed a key when current letter matched the one n positions earlier. Training consisted of 9 blocks per session with 6 targets per block.
RoB2_Notes: RoB2_01: Described as "pseudo-randomly" assigned taking into account gender, age and education, but specific randomization method not detailed. RoB2_02: Training protocol was clearly defined and consistently implemented across participants. RoB2_03: Low attrition rate (9.5%) with clear reporting of dropouts. RoB2_04: Outcome assessors likely aware of intervention status as no blinding was mentioned. RoB2_05: No pre-registration mentioned, but all expected outcomes were reported.
Notes_From_File: the X-back task was a control condition, and not a cognitive assessment. Thus, I didn't include it.

Title: "Enhancing Cognitive Abilities with Comprehensive Training: A Large, Online, Randomized, Active-Controlled Trial"
Citation: "Hardy, J. L., Nelson, R. A., Thomason, M. E., Sternberg, D. A., Katovich, K., Farzin, F., & Scanlon, M. (2015). Enhancing cognitive abilities with comprehensive training: A large, online, randomized, active-controlled trial. PLOS ONE, 10(9), e0134467. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0134467"
Recruitment_Method: Online recruitment from Lumosity website users
Control_Group_Description: Crossword puzzles of medium difficulty (approximately equivalent to a Thursday New York Times crossword puzzle)
Intervention_Description: "Lumosity cognitive training program with 49 tasks targeting speed of processing, attention, memory, flexibility, and problem solving"
Cognitive_Activity_Description: "Daily training sessions of five cognitive training tasks chosen by an algorithm to optimize balance of training activities across speed of processing, attention, memory, flexibility, and problem solving domains"
RoB2_Notes: High attrition rate (52.5%) is the main concern. Randomization was well-described. Some concerns about deviations as some control participants accessed cognitive training. Outcome measurement was automated and standardized.
Notes_From_File: SENSITIVITY: some participants over 65yo; no morris-method because change scores reported
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: SENSITIVITY: some participants over 65yo; no morris-method because change scores reported

Title: "Enhancing Cognitive Abilities with Comprehensive Training: A Large, Online, Randomized, Active-Controlled Trial"
Citation: "Hardy, J. L., Nelson, R. A., Thomason, M. E., Sternberg, D. A., Katovich, K., Farzin, F., & Scanlon, M. (2015). Enhancing cognitive abilities with comprehensive training: A large, online, randomized, active-controlled trial. PLOS ONE, 10(9), e0134467. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0134467"
Recruitment_Method: Online recruitment from Lumosity website users
Control_Group_Description: Crossword puzzles of medium difficulty (approximately equivalent to a Thursday New York Times crossword puzzle)
Intervention_Description: "Lumosity cognitive training program with 49 tasks targeting speed of processing, attention, memory, flexibility, and problem solving"
Cognitive_Activity_Description: "Daily training sessions of five cognitive training tasks chosen by an algorithm to optimize balance of training activities across speed of processing, attention, memory, flexibility, and problem solving domains"
RoB2_Notes: High attrition rate (52.5%) is the main concern. Randomization was well-described. Some concerns about deviations as some control participants accessed cognitive training. Outcome measurement was automated and standardized.
Notes_From_File: SENSITIVITY: some participants over 65yo; no morris-method because change scores reported
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: SENSITIVITY: some participants over 65yo; no morris-method because change scores reported

Title: Working memory training improvements and gains in non-trained cognitive tasks in young and older adults
Citation: Heinzel, S., Schulte, S., Onken, J., Duong, Q. L., Riemer, T. G., Heinz, A., Kathmann, N., & Rapp, M. A. (2013). Working memory training improvements and gains in non-trained cognitive tasks in young and older adults. Aging, Neuropsychology, and Cognition, 20(6), 1-28. https://doi.org/10.1080/13825585.2013.790338
Recruitment_Method: Newspaper advertisements, email, and blackboard notes at university and sports clubs for senior citizens
Control_Group_Description: No-contact control group that did not participate in training
Intervention_Description: Adaptive n-back working memory training with increasing difficulty by manipulating working memory load and presentation speed
Cognitive_Activity_Description: n-back task with digits from 0-9 visually presented in the center of a black screen in randomized sequence one at a time, with varying levels of n (0 to 5) and interstimulus intervals (1800 to 1000 ms)
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; No blinding of participants or personnel reported; No missing outcome data (0% attrition); No information about blinding of outcome assessors; No pre-registration but all expected outcomes reported.
Notes_From_File: SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS: comparisons 9-16 are with group that partly exceeds age range
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS: comparisons 9-16 are with group that partly exceeds age range

Title: The Effects of Physical Exercise and Cognitive Training on Memory and Neurotrophic Factors
Citation: Heisz, J. J., Clark, I. B., Bonin, K., Paolucci, E. M., Michalski, B., Becker, S., & Fahnestock, M. (2017). The effects of physical exercise and cognitive training on memory and neurotrophic factors. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 29(11), 1895-1907. https://doi.org/10.1162/jocn_a_01164
Control_Group_Description: No training control group that remained sedentary for 6 weeks
Intervention_Description: High-intensity interval training (HIT) on stationary cycle ergometers. Protocol consisted of 3-min warm up with 50W resistance, followed by 10 alternating high-intensity (60-sec at ~80% maximum wattage and ~90-95% peak HR) and recovery (60-sec at ~30% maximum wattage, â‰¥50W) intervals, and 2-min cool down at 50W.
Physical_Activity_Description: High-intensity interval training (HIT) on stationary cycle ergometers with 10 alternating high-intensity and recovery intervals
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Interventions were supervised in laboratory setting minimizing deviations; Moderate attrition (13-17%) with no explanation of how missing data was handled; Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded; No pre-registration and evidence of selective analysis based on responder status.

Title: The Effects of Physical Exercise and Cognitive Training on Memory and Neurotrophic Factors
Citation: Heisz, J. J., Clark, I. B., Bonin, K., Paolucci, E. M., Michalski, B., Becker, S., & Fahnestock, M. (2017). The effects of physical exercise and cognitive training on memory and neurotrophic factors. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 29(11), 1895-1907. https://doi.org/10.1162/jocn_a_01164

Protocol consisted of 3-min warm up with 50W resistance, followed by 10 alternating high-intensity (60-sec at ~80% maximum wattage and ~90-95% peak HR) and recovery (60-sec at ~30% maximum wattage, â‰¥50W) intervals, and 2-min cool down at 50W.
Physical_Activity_Description: High-intensity interval training (HIT) on stationary cycle ergometers with 10 alternating high-intensity and recovery intervals
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Interventions were supervised in laboratory setting minimizing deviations; Moderate attrition (13-17%) with no explanation of how missing data was handled; Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded; No pre-registration and evidence of selective analysis based on responder status.

Title: The Effects of Physical Exercise and Cognitive Training on Memory and Neurotrophic Factors
Citation: Heisz, J. J., Clark, I. B., Bonin, K., Paolucci, E. M., Michalski, B., Becker, S., & Fahnestock, M. (2017). The effects of physical exercise and cognitive training on memory and neurotrophic factors. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 29(11), 1895-1907. https://doi.org/10.1162/jocn_a_01164
Control_Group_Description: No training control group that remained sedentary for 6 weeks
Intervention_Description: Combined exercise and cognitive training: HIT exercise (20 min) plus computerized Concentration Memory Task (20 min) completed on the same day during the same session
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Computerized Concentration Memory Task (Pelmanism) with adaptive difficulty levels (1-9) using face pairs with high interference, testing delayed memory performance after 5 minutes
Physical_Activity_Description: High-intensity interval training (HIT) on stationary cycle ergometers with 10 alternating high-intensity and recovery intervals
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Interventions were supervised in laboratory setting minimizing deviations; Moderate attrition (13-17%) with no explanation of how missing data was handled; Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded; No pre-registration and evidence of selective analysis based on responder status.
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Combined exercise and cognitive training performed on same day during same session

Title: Differential Cognitive Effects of Cycling Versus Stretching/Coordination Training in Middle-Aged Adults
Citation: Hötting, K., Reich, B., Holzschneider, K., Kauschke, K., Schmidt, T., Reer, R., Braumann, K. M., & Röder, B. (2012). Differential cognitive effects of cycling versus stretching/coordination training in middle-aged adults. Health Psychology, 31(2), 145-155. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0025371
Recruitment_Method: Advertisements in local newspapers, local radio stations, and announcements in shops, cinemas, and companies
Control_Group_Description: Sedentary control group without exercise intervention
Intervention_Description: Aerobic endurance training on stationary indoor bicycles with heart rate monitoring. Intensity was adjusted to reach 85% of individual aerobic-anaerobic threshold for approximately 45 minutes per session.
Physical_Activity_Description: Cycling on stationary indoor bicycles with heart rate monitoring, intensity adjusted to 85% of individual aerobic-anaerobic threshold
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Interventions were well-controlled with heart rate monitoring; Dropout rate was 24% but did not differ between groups; No information about blinding of outcome assessors; No pre-registration but all expected outcomes reported.

Title: Short-Term High-Intensity Interval Exercise Promotes Motor Cortex Plasticity and Executive Function in Sedentary Females
Citation: Hu, M., Zeng, N., Gu, Z., Zheng, Y., Xu, K., Xue, L., Leng, L., Lu, X., Shen, Y., & Huang, J. (2021). Short-Term High-Intensity Interval Exercise Promotes Motor Cortex Plasticity and Executive Function in Sedentary Females. Frontiers in Human Neuroscience, 15, 620958. https://doi.org/10.3389/fnhum.2021.620958
Control_Group_Description: No intervention, maintained normal lifestyle
Intervention_Description: High-intensity interval training on a stationary power bike, alternating between 50% HRR for 3 min and 90% HRR for 2 min, 4 times per session, with 2-min warm-up and 2-min cool-down
Physical_Activity_Description: High-intensity interval training on a stationary power bike with alternating intensity levels
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; No missing outcome data reported; Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded; Study was registered (ChiCTR1900028645) but no pre-specified analysis plan was mentioned; No evidence of selective reporting but lack of detailed pre-registration information raises some concerns.
Variance_Conversion_Notes: Control PRE: Converted from SEM=24.300000, N=16; Control POST: Converted from SEM=22.370000, N=16; Intervention PRE: Converted from SEM=18.250000, N=16; Intervention POST: Converted from SEM=20.630000, N=16

Title: Minds "At Attention": Mindfulness Training Curbs Attentional Lapses in Military Cohorts
Citation: Jha, A. P., Morrison, A. B., Dainer-Best, J., Parker, S., Rostrup, N., & Stanley, E. A. (2015). Minds "At Attention": Mindfulness Training Curbs Attentional Lapses in Military Cohorts. PLOS ONE, 10(2), e0116889. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0116889
Control_Group_Description: Military service members not receiving mindfulness training
Intervention_Description: Training-focused Mindfulness-based Mind Fitness Training (MMFT) emphasizing in-class practice of mindfulness exercises and group discussion
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Mindfulness exercises focusing on attention to present moment experience, body sensations, and redirecting attention when mind wandering occurs
RoB2_Notes: Randomization was not at individual level but by military unit (high risk); Some participants withdrew due to scheduling conflicts (some concerns); Attrition of 11.8% with participants excluded for not following task instructions (some concerns); Outcome measurement was objective and computerized (low risk); No pre-registration mentioned and multiple outcomes reported (some concerns)
Notes_From_File: SENSITIVITY: mindfulness intervention
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: SENSITIVITY:

Citation: Jha, A. P., Morrison, A. B., Dainer-Best, J., Parker, S., Rostrup, N., & Stanley, E. A. (2015). Minds "At Attention": Mindfulness Training Curbs Attentional Lapses in Military Cohorts. PLOS ONE, 10(2), e0116889. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0116889
Control_Group_Description: Military service members not receiving mindfulness training
Intervention_Description: Didactic-focused Mindfulness-based Mind Fitness Training (MMFT) emphasizing lectures and minimal in-class practice
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Didactic instruction on mindfulness with minimal practice
RoB2_Notes: Randomization was not at individual level but by military unit (high risk); Some participants withdrew due to scheduling conflicts (some concerns); Attrition of 11.8% with participants excluded for not following task instructions (some concerns); Outcome measurement was objective and computerized (low risk); No pre-registration mentioned and multiple outcomes reported (some concerns)
Notes_From_File: SENSITIVITY: mindfulness intervention
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: SENSITIVITY:

Title: Effects of motor-cognitive coordination training and cardiovascular training on motor coordination and cognitive functions
Citation: Johann, V. E., Stenger, K., Kersten, S., & Karbach, J. (2016). Effects of motor-cognitive coordination training and cardiovascular training on motor coordination and cognitive functions. Psychology of Sport and Exercise, 24, 118-127. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.psychsport.2016.01.008
Control_Group_Description: No training control group (physically active participants)
Intervention_Description: Motor-cognitive coordination training based on Lifekinetic regime with three exercises of increasing complexity combined with cognitive tasks
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Coordination exercises combined with cognitive tasks requiring working memory, inhibition, cognitive flexibility, and attention
Physical_Activity_Description: Motor coordination tasks with increasing complexity requiring balance and coordination
RoB2_Notes: Participants were randomized to groups and matched for age and gender (low risk); Supervised training with high adherence (low risk); 16.1% attrition with 5 dropouts (some concerns); Objective computerized cognitive measures (low risk); No pre-registration mentioned (some concerns)
Notes_From_File: The coordination exercise group has cognitive components, leading me to classify it as a mixed intervention

Citation: Johann, V. E., Stenger, K., Kersten, S., & Karbach, J. (2016). Effects of motor-cognitive coordination training and cardiovascular training on motor coordination and cognitive functions. Psychology of Sport and Exercise, 24, 118-127. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.psychsport.2016.01.008
Control_Group_Description: No training control group (sedentary participants)
Intervention_Description: Motor-cognitive coordination training based on Lifekinetic regime with three exercises of increasing complexity combined with cognitive tasks

Physical_Activity_Description: Motor coordination tasks with increasing complexity requiring balance and coordination
RoB2_Notes: Participants were randomized to groups and matched for age and gender (low risk); Supervised training with high adherence (low risk); 25.0% attrition with 10 dropouts (some concerns); Objective computerized cognitive measures (low risk); No pre-registration mentioned (some concerns)

Title: The effect of regular Taekwondo exercise on Brain-derived neurotrophic factor and Stroop test in undergraduate student
Citation: Kim, Y. (2015). The effect of regular Taekwondo exercise on Brain-derived neurotrophic factor and Stroop test in undergraduate student. Journal of Exercise Nutrition & Biochemistry, 19(2), 73-79. http://dx.doi.org/10.5717/jenb.2015.15060904
Variable_Value: Number of correct items in 45 seconds
Control_Group_Description: No exercise control group
Intervention_Description: Taekwondo exercise program consisting of aerobic training (20 min) and dynamic exercise training (65 min) including Mitt-target exercises, isometric exercises, and jumping exercises
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Taekwondo training involving complex motor skills, coordination, and attention
Physical_Activity_Description: Aerobic exercise (jogging), dynamic exercise (kicking techniques), and explosive exercise (jumping)
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; No missing outcome data (all participants completed the study); No information about blinding of outcome assessors; No pre-registration but all expected outcomes reported; No evidence of selective reporting but no pre-specified analysis plan available.
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Combined aerobic exercise (20 min jogging) and dynamic exercise (65 min of kicking techniques, isometric exercises, and jumping exercises)

Title: Cognitive Training Prevents Stress-Induced Working Memory Deficits
Journal: Biological Psychiatry: Cognitive Neuroscience and Neuroimaging
Citation: Loock, K., & Schwabe, L. (2024). Cognitive Training Prevents Stress-Induced Working Memory Deficits. Biological Psychiatry: Cognitive Neuroscience and Neuroimaging, 9(10), 1039-1047. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bpsc.2024.06.006
Control_Group_Description: Sham training group that trained on visual tasks with minimal working memory components
Intervention_Description: Daily cognitive training program targeting working memory-related processes using memory and logical reasoning tasks primarily based on prefrontal and medial temporal functioning
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Five different tasks designed to train cognitive abilities in a playful way, focusing on memory and logical reasoning
RoB2_Notes: Study was preregistered and followed a clear protocol with appropriate randomization procedures. Participants were randomly assigned to conditions based on an a priori randomized sequence. All participants completed the full training program with no significant deviations. Only 6 participants were excluded for valid reasons (technical failures or being statistical outliers). Outcome assessment was objective using computerized n-back task. The study was preregistered in the German Clinical Trials Register (DRKS-ID: DRKS00025559) and all planned outcomes were reported.

Title: How does a 4-week motor"“cognitive training affect choice reaction, dynamic balance and cognitive performance ability? A randomized controlled trial in well-trained, young, healthy participants
Citation: Niederer, D., Plaumann, U., Seitz, T., Wallner, F., Wilke, J., Engeroff, T., Giesche, F., Vogt, L., & Banzer, W. (2019). How does a 4-week motor"“cognitive training affect choice reaction, dynamic balance and cognitive performance ability? A randomized controlled trial in well-trained, young, healthy participants. SAGE Open Medicine, 7, 1-8. https://doi.org/10.1177/2050312119870020
Control_Group_Description: No treatment
Intervention_Description: Motor-cognitive dual-task training derived from Life Kinetik concept. Ten different exercises were performed, each lasting at least 2 minutes. Tasks included throwing balls, jumping through speed ladders with cognitive perturbation, walking and throwing balls with commands, passing balls, dancing with scarfs, finger skills, hand skills, head skills, march parade, and imitation exercises.
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Cognitive perturbation tasks requiring attention, working memory, and coordination
Physical_Activity_Description: Motor coordination exercises including throwing, jumping, dancing, and movement sequences
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned as complete balanced randomization using BIAS software but specific method not detailed. Intervention adherence was good (88%). Low attrition (7.7%). No blinding of outcome assessors mentioned for objective measures. For self-reported outcomes, high risk of bias due to participant awareness of intervention status. No pre-registered protocol mentioned, but all expected outcomes appear to be reported.
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Combined motor and cognitive dual-task training
Notes_From_File: only change scores/SDs reported

Title: Mindfulness Training Enhances Endurance Performance and Executive Functions in Athletes: An Event-Related Potential Study
Citation: Nien, J. T., Wu, C. H., Yang, K. T., Cho, Y. M., Chu, C. H., Chang, Y. K., & Zhou, C. (2020). Mindfulness training enhances endurance performance and executive functions in athletes: An event-related potential study. Neural Plasticity, 2020, 8213710. https://doi.org/10.1155/2020/8213710
Control_Group_Description: Waiting list control group that maintained daily routines
Intervention_Description: Five-week mindfulness training program based on original mindfulness program and mindful sport performance enhancement (MSPE), including mindful breathing, mindful meditation, body scanning, mindful yoga, and mindful walking
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Mindfulness training including attention focus, awareness exercises, and executive control practices
Physical_Activity_Description: Mindful yoga and mindful walking components
RoB2_Notes: High risk for randomization as participants were assigned based on voluntary willingness rather than true randomization (quasi-experimental design). Low attrition with complete data. Some concerns for measurement as participants could not be blinded to mindfulness intervention. Some concerns for selection as no pre-registration mentioned but expected outcomes reported.
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Combined mindfulness meditation with physical mindfulness activities

Title: Game-based training of flexibility and attention improves task-switch performance: near and far transfer of cognitive training in an EEG study
Citation: Olfers, K. J. F., & Band, G. P. H. (2018). Game-based training of flexibility and attention improves task-switch performance: near and far transfer of cognitive training in an EEG study. Psychological Research, 82, 186-202. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00426-017-0933-z
Control_Group_Description: Math games training (arithmetic games as active control)
Intervention_Description: Flexibility training with games targeting task switching and cognitive flexibility (Task Switch Challenge, Color Match, Lost in Migration, Disillusion)
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Task switching and cognitive flexibility training games
RoB2_Notes: Proper randomization mentioned with balanced baseline characteristics. Good adherence and low attrition. Computerized outcome measurement reduces bias. Some concerns for selection as no pre-registration mentioned but comprehensive outcome reporting. Active control design appropriate for isolating specific training effects.

Title: Increasing Working Memory in Young Healthy Adults: a Cluster Randomized Controlled Trial of a Multifaceted Brain Training Intervention
Citation: Ørskov, P. T., Norup, A., Debrabant, B., & Beatty, E. L. (2020). Increasing Working Memory in Young Healthy Adults: a Cluster Randomized Controlled Trial of a Multifaceted Brain Training Intervention. Journal of Cognitive Enhancement. https://doi.org/10.1007/s41465-020-00191-3
Recruitment_Method: School-based recruitment from 17 Danish upper secondary education schools
Control_Group_Description: No intervention, assessment only
Intervention_Description: Multifaceted Brain Training (MBT) combining physical and cognitive elements, facilitated by classroom teacher. Included diverse cognitive tasks, meta-cognitive strategies, and low-intensity physical activity in a group setting.
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Working memory training, attention training, cognitive flexibility training. Diverse cognitive tasks targeting working memory, attention, and cognitive flexibility with visualization exercises and meta-cognitive strategies.
Physical_Activity_Description: Low-intensity physical activity. Simple physical exercises combined with cognitive tasks, bilateral coordination exercises, and eye tracking exercises. Not intense enough to elicit changes in aerobic capacity.
RoB2_Notes: Randomization was properly conducted at class level with stratification by school and block randomization (Low Risk). Some concerns about deviations as blinding was not possible and adherence was low. High attrition rate (31%) raises some concerns about missing data, though ITT analysis was used. Online assessment under teacher supervision raises some concerns about measurement bias. Pre-registration and comprehensive reporting reduces selection bias (Low Risk).
Intervention_Adherence: Low adherence noted in sensitivity analysis
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Combined cognitive training with physical activity and social interaction in a classroom setting. Included visualization exercises, cognitive tasks with increasing difficulty, and meta-cognitive strategies.
Notes_From_File: SENSITIVITY: some participants are <18yo; INFERENCE: the post-test variance values were reported as SD but they are obviously SEM... I emailed the authors to confirm, but it is obvious.
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: SENSITIVITY: some participants are <18yo; INFERENCE: the post-test variance values were reported as SD but they are obviously SEM... I emailed the authors to confirm, but it is obvious.
Variance_Conversion_Notes: Control POST: Converted from SEM=0.570000, N=719; Intervention POST: Converted from SEM=0.510000, N=916

Title: Does reformer pilates exercise improve cognitive functions in sedentary women? A randomized controlled study
Citation: Özeren, A., UlučŸ, N., Şahan, N., & Can Karahan, Z. (2024). Does reformer pilates exercise improve cognitive functions in sedentary women? A randomized controlled study. Journal of Bodywork & Movement Therapies, 40, 1899-1905. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jbmt.2024.10.031
Recruitment_Method: Convenience sampling from clients seeking exercise counselling at Private Middle East Hospital
Control_Group_Description: No exercise program, sedentary women waiting to start reformer pilates
Intervention_Description: Reformer Pilates exercises including footwork series, supine armwork, feet in straps, upper stretching exercise (elephant), longbox series, plank, knee stretch, back extensors strengthening, posture exercises, standing hip stretching exercises
Physical_Activity_Description: Reformer Pilates exercises focusing on core strength, flexibility, and body control
Exercise_Intensity_Reported: Progressive intensity (6-8 repetitions initially, increased weekly)
RoB2_Notes: Randomization process was well-described using block randomization with www.randomizer.org (Low Risk). Intervention was delivered as intended with clear protocol (Low Risk). Missing outcome data was minimal with 6 dropouts from 50 participants and analysis was per protocol (Low Risk). Some concerns about measurement of outcome as participants were not blinded to group allocation which could influence performance on cognitive tests (Some Concerns). Study was pre-registered (NCT05932004) and all expected outcomes were reported (Low Risk).

Title: Computerised working memory training in healthy adults: A comparison of two different training schedules
Citation: Penner, I. K., Vogt, A., Stöcklin, M., Gschwind, L., Opwis, K., & Calabrese, P. (2012). Computerised working memory training in healthy adults: A comparison of two different training schedules. Neuropsychological Rehabilitation, 22(5), 716-733. https://doi.org/10.1080/09602011.2012.686883
Control_Group_Description: No training control group that only completed cognitive assessments at baseline and after training period
Intervention_Description: High-intensity computerized working memory training using BrainStim software with three modules (City Map, Find Pairs, Memorise Numbers) - 4 weeks, 4 sessions per week
Cognitive_Activity_Description: BrainStim software with three modules: City Map (spatial orientation with visual/verbal instructions), Find Pairs (visual object memory and updating function), and Memorise Numbers (remembering digits with arithmetic distraction task)
RoB2_Notes: Randomization Process: Some Concerns - Article states participants were allocated based on demographic data rather than true randomization. Deviations: Low Risk - All participants completed training with high adherence. Missing Data: Low Risk - No attrition reported. Measurement: Some Concerns - No mention of blinding of outcome assessors. Selection of Results: Some Concerns - No pre-registration mentioned and no explicit analysis plan described.

Citation: Penner, I. K., Vogt, A., Stöcklin, M., Gschwind, L., Opwis, K., & Calabrese, P. (2012). Computerised working memory training in healthy adults: A comparison of two different training schedules. Neuropsychological Rehabilitation, 22(5), 716-733. https://doi.org/10.1080/09602011.2012.686883
Control_Group_Description: No training control group that only completed cognitive assessments at baseline and after training period
Intervention_Description: High-intensity computerized working memory training using BrainStim software with three modules (City Map, Find Pairs, Memorise Numbers) - 4 weeks, 4 sessions per week
Cognitive_Activity_Description: BrainStim software with three modules: City Map (spatial orientation with visual/verbal instructions), Find Pairs (visual object memory and updating function), and Memorise Numbers (remembering digits with arithmetic distraction task)

Title: Feasibility and impact of a remote moderate-intensity yoga intervention on stress and executive functioning in working adults: a randomized controlled trial
Citation: Phansikar, M., Gothe, N., Hernandez, R., Lara-Cinisomo, S., & Mullen, S. P. (2022). Feasibility and impact of a remote moderate-intensity yoga intervention on stress and executive functioning in working adults: a randomized controlled trial. Journal of Behavioral Medicine. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10865-022-00385-4
Control_Group_Description: Waitlist control group asked to carry on with their lives as usual, and refrain from starting any new physical activity practice
Intervention_Description: Moderate-intensity yoga intervention consisting of sun salutation sequences from Hatha yoga and sun salutations A and B often performed in Ashtanga and Vinyasa yoga, followed by breathing exercises and guided relaxation
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Yoga practice requiring participants to remember sequences of postures that changed every week and to remember various dynamic modifications and additions to each posture in the sequence
Physical_Activity_Description: Moderate-intensity yoga involving sun salutation sequences, with poses and movements done for 35-40 min, followed by 5-7 min of breathing and 5 min of guided relaxation
Activity_Presentation: Remote delivery via synchronous live sessions and asynchronous self-guided videos
Exercise_Intensity_Reported: Moderate intensity yoga with heart rate 117-127 bpm
RoB2_Notes: Randomization was properly conducted using block-order stratification through Microsoft Excel with 1:1 allocation ratio and block size of 10, stratified by age and sex. Some concerns about deviations from intended interventions due to lower adherence to self-guided sessions (63.5%) compared to supervised sessions (97.15%). Low risk for missing outcome data as ITT analysis was used with multiple imputation for the 3 participants who did not complete post-testing. Some concerns about measurement of outcome as cognitive assessments were conducted remotely without standardized testing conditions. Low risk for selection of reported results as the study was pre-registered on ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT04740229).
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Combined physical yoga practice with breathing exercises and guided relaxation

Title: Effects of Aerobic Exercise on Cognitive and Psychosocial Functioning in Patients With Mild Hypertension
Citation: Pierce, T. W., Madden, D. J., Siegel, W. C., & Blumenthal, J. A. (1993). Effects of aerobic exercise on cognitive and psychosocial functioning in patients with mild hypertension. Health Psychology, 12(4), 286-291. https://doi.org/10.1037/0278-6133.12.4.286
Control_Group_Description: Waiting list control group asked to make no change in exercise behavior during the 16 weeks
Intervention_Description: Aerobic exercise consisting of walking, jogging, or both at an intensity of at least 70% of subjects' initial VO2max
Physical_Activity_Description: Walking and jogging at an intensity of at least 70% of subjects' initial VO2max
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Intervention adherence was monitored and reported (84% attendance); Low attrition rate (9.1%) with complete data for 90 of 99 participants; No information about blinding of outcome assessors; No pre-registered protocol but all expected cognitive outcomes reported
Test_Name_Standardized: Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale - Digit Symbol

Control_Group_Description: Waiting list control group asked to make no change in exercise behavior during the 16 weeks
Intervention_Description: Strength training and flexibility exercise consisting of 20 min of flexibility exercises followed by 30 min of circuit weight training
Physical_Activity_Description: Strength training and flexibility exercises with no cardiovascular training effects
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Intervention adherence was monitored and reported (89% attendance); Low attrition rate (9.1%) with complete data for 90 of 99 participants; No information about blinding of outcome assessors; No pre-registered protocol but all expected cognitive outcomes reported

Title: Adaptive working memory training does not produce transfer effects in cognition and neuroimaging
Citation: Ripp, I., Emch, M., Wu, Q., Lizarraga, A., Udale, R., von Bastian, C. C., Koch, K., & Yakushev, I. (2022). Adaptive working memory training does not produce transfer effects in cognition and neuroimaging. Translational Psychiatry, 12(1), 512. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41398-022-02272-7
Recruitment_Method: Advertisements on internet and hospital bulletin boards
Control_Group_Description: Non-adaptive low-level training with visual (X-back) and verbal (1-back) tasks
Intervention_Description: Adaptive n-back training with visual and verbal tasks. Task difficulty (n-back level) was adapted based on performance, increasing if proportion of correct responses was >90% and decreasing if <80%.
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Adaptive n-back training with visual and verbal tasks. Each training session included 9 blocks per task (18 blocks total). Each block had 6 targets and 14 non-targets.
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Participants were supervised and training was monitored; Very low attrition rate (1.8%); Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded; No pre-registration mentioned but all expected outcomes reported.

Test_Name: Raven Advanced Progressive Matrices Short Form (Short-APM)
Title: Adaptive working memory training does not produce transfer effects in cognition and neuroimaging
Citation: Ripp, I., Emch, M., Wu, Q., Lizarraga, A., Udale, R., von Bastian, C. C., Koch, K., & Yakushev, I. (2022). Adaptive working memory training does not produce transfer effects in cognition and neuroimaging. Translational Psychiatry, 12(1), 512. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41398-022-02272-7
Recruitment_Method: Advertisements on internet and hospital bulletin boards
Control_Group_Description: Non-adaptive low-level training with visual (X-back) and verbal (1-back) tasks
Intervention_Description: Adaptive n-back training with visual and verbal tasks. Task difficulty (n-back level) was adapted based on performance, increasing if proportion of correct responses was >90% and decreasing if <80%.
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Adaptive n-back training with visual and verbal tasks. Each training session included 9 blocks per task (18 blocks total). Each block had 6 targets and 14 non-targets.
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Participants were supervised and training was monitored; Very low attrition rate (1.8%); Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded; No pre-registration mentioned but all expected outcomes reported.
Test_Name_Standardized: Raven Advanced Progressive Matrices - Short Form (RAPM-SF)

Title: A Potential Spatial Working Memory Training Task to Improve Both Episodic Memory and Fluid Intelligence
Citation: Rudebeck, S. R., Bor, D., Ormond, A., O'Reilly, J. X., & Lee, A. C. H. (2012). A potential spatial working memory training task to improve both episodic memory and fluid intelligence. PLoS ONE, 7(11), e50431. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0050431
Control_Group_Description: No-contact control group that completed the same assessments 28 days apart but did not undertake any cognitive training
Intervention_Description: Adaptive spatial working memory training using dual n-back task with scene images and spatial locations presented in 3D room
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Adaptive dual n-back task with spatial and scene components targeting working memory
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified. No information about blinding of participants or personnel. Very low attrition rate (1.8%) with only one participant excluded. No information about blinding of outcome assessors. No pre-registered protocol but all expected outcomes reported. Statistical data verified against PDF Table 2.
Intervention_Adherence: Good completion rate with home-based training

Title: Effects of a 14-Day Healthy Longevity Lifestyle Program on Cognition and Brain Function
Citation: Small, G. W., Silverman, D. H. S., Siddarth, P., Ercoli, L. M., Miller, K. J., Lavretsky, H., Wright, B. C., Bookheimer, S. Y., Barrio, J. R., & Phelps, M. E. (2006). Effects of a 14-day healthy longevity lifestyle program on cognition and brain function. American Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry, 14(6), 538-545.
Recruitment_Method: Advertisements, media coverage, and physician/family referrals
Control_Group_Description: Usual lifestyle habits
Intervention_Description: 14-day healthy longevity lifestyle program combining memory training, physical conditioning, relaxation techniques, and healthy diet
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Brain teasers, mental puzzles, and memory techniques (attention focusing, visualization, association skills)
Physical_Activity_Description: Brisk walks
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified. No information on blinding of participants or personnel. No missing outcome data reported. Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded. No pre-registered protocol mentioned but expected outcomes reported.
Intervention_Adherence: Good compliance monitored by research nurse
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Program combining memory training, physical exercise, relaxation exercises, and healthy diet
Notes_From_File: SENSITIVITY: some participants are above 65yo
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: SENSITIVITY: some participants are above 65yo

Title: Effect of aerobic exercise on cognition in younger adults: A randomized clinical trial
Citation: Stern, Y., MacKay-Brandt, A., Lee, S., McKinley, P., McIntyre, K., Razlighi, Q., Agarunov, E., Bartels, M., & Sloan, R. P. (2019). Effect of aerobic exercise on cognition in younger adults: A randomized clinical trial. Neurology, 92(9), e905-e916. https://doi.org/10.1212/WNL.0000000000007003
Control_Group_Description: Stretching/toning exercises for 24 weeks, 4 sessions/week, 30-40 minutes per session
Intervention_Description: Aerobic exercise training for 24 weeks, 4 sessions/week, 30-40 minutes per session, with target heart rate of 75% of maximum
Physical_Activity_Description: Aerobic exercise with participant choice of activity, maintaining target heart rate
RoB2_Notes: The study used proper randomization with allocation ratio of 1:1 and concealed allocation. Some concerns about deviations from intended interventions due to lack of blinding of participants and higher dropout in aerobic group (33.33% vs 24.24% in stretching). Missing outcome data concerns due to differential attrition between groups with older participants adhering better in aerobic group (OR=1.054 per year, p=0.0292). Outcome assessors were masked to group assignment. Pre-registered on ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01179958) with outcomes reported as planned.
Notes_From_File: mean changes reported, not pretest and posttest measures; I used very conservative estimates for session length when extracting intervention details
Variance_Conversion_Notes: Control: Converted from SEM=0.160000, N=50; Intervention: Converted from SEM=0.310000, N=44

Test_Name: Visual and Verbal Memory Test (VVM Visuospatial)
Title: Aerobic endurance exercise benefits memory and affect in young adults
Citation: Stroth, S., Hille, K., Spitzer, M., & Reinhardt, R. (2009). Aerobic endurance exercise benefits memory and affect in young adults. Neuropsychological Rehabilitation: An International Journal, 19(2), 223-243. https://doi.org/10.1080/09602010802091183
Control_Group_Description: No intervention, asked not to vary everyday activities
Intervention_Description: Aerobic endurance running training with three workouts of 30 minutes per week at individually adapted intensity based on lactate threshold
Physical_Activity_Description: Aerobic endurance running with progressive intensity: weeks 1-2 at 70-90% of aerobic threshold, weeks 3-4 at 90-100% of aerobic threshold, weeks 5-6 at 70-100% of aerobic threshold
RoB2_Notes: Randomization: Some concerns as the method of randomization was not fully described. Deviations: Low risk as adherence was almost 100% and the intervention was delivered as intended. Missing data: Low risk as attrition was low (7.14%) and analyzed appropriately. Measurement: Some concerns as assessors were not explicitly blinded to group allocation. Selection of results: Some concerns as no pre-registration was mentioned, though all expected outcomes were reported.
Test_Name_Standardized: Visual and Verbal Memory Test - Visuospatial

Control_Group_Description: No intervention, asked not to vary everyday activities
Intervention_Description: Aerobic endurance running training with three workouts of 30 minutes per week at individually adapted intensity based on lactate threshold
Physical_Activity_Description: Aerobic endurance running with progressive intensity: weeks 1-2 at 70-90% of aerobic threshold, weeks 3-4 at 90-100% of aerobic threshold, weeks 5-6 at 70-100% of aerobic threshold
RoB2_Notes: Randomization: Some concerns as the method of randomization was not fully described. Deviations: Low risk as adherence was almost 100% and the intervention was delivered as intended. Missing data: Low risk as attrition was low (7.14%) and analyzed appropriately. Measurement: Some concerns as assessors were not explicitly blinded to group allocation. Selection of results: Some concerns as no pre-registration was mentioned, though all expected outcomes were reported.

Title: Aerobic Exercise Improves Attention and Quality of Sleep Among Professional Volleyball Players
Citation: Taheri, M., & Valayi, F. (2018). Aerobic Exercise Improves Attention and Quality of Sleep Among Professional Volleyball Players. Sleep and Hypnosis, 21(1), 69-72. https://doi.org/10.5350/Sleep.Hypn.2019.21.0174
Control_Group_Description: No intervention
Intervention_Description: Aerobic exercise protocol including warm-up (10 minutes with 30-40% MaxHR), main program (40 minutes of aerobic exercises with 60-70% MaxHR), and cool-down (10 minutes with 10-20% MaxHR)
Physical_Activity_Description: Aerobic exercise with 60-70% of maximum heart rate
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; No attrition reported (100% completion); No information about blinding of outcome assessors; No pre-registration mentioned but expected outcomes reported; Exercise intensity was monitored with Polar Electro.

Title: Interval running training improves cognitive flexibility and aerobic power of young healthy adults
Journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
Citation: Venckunas, T., Snieckus, A., Trinkunas, E., Baranauskiene, N., Solianik, R., Juodsnukis, A., Streckis, V., & Kamandulis, S. (2016). Interval running training improves cognitive flexibility and aerobic power of young healthy adults. Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research, 30(8), 2114-2121.
Control_Group_Description: Healthy age-matched subjects who continued their active lifestyle without any regular training
Intervention_Description: Interval running training consisting of 200-1000m intervals with progressive increase in repetitions each week
Physical_Activity_Description: Interval running with 200-1000m intervals, progressively increasing in repetitions each week
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; High attrition rate (22.2%) but all remaining participants complied with protocol; No information about blinding of outcome assessors; No pre-registration or protocol available but all expected outcomes reported

Title: Effects of 12 weeks of aerobic exercise combined with resistance training on neurocognitive performance in obese women
Citation: Wen, H. J., Liu, S. H., & Tsai, C. L. (2022). Effects of 12 weeks of aerobic exercise combined with resistance training on neurocognitive performance in obese women. Journal of Exercise Science & Fitness, 20, 291-304. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jesf.2022.07.001
Recruitment_Method: Community advertisement (local radio station and newspaper)
Control_Group_Description: Maintained regular lifestyle without engaging in any type of exercise
Intervention_Description: 30 min of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise combined with resistance exercise, including 3-5 min warm-up, 30-min supervised moderate-intensity aerobic dance alternately combined with dumbbell resistance exercises, followed by 3-5 min cool-down
Physical_Activity_Description: Moderate-intensity aerobic dance alternately combined with dumbbell resistance exercises
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; No blinding of participants or personnel reported; No missing outcome data (0% attrition); Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded; No pre-registered protocol available but expected outcomes reported
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Combined aerobic exercise (dance) with resistance training (dumbbells)
Notes_From_File: obese participants (include)

Title: Mindfulness Training as Cognitive Training in High-Demand Cohorts: An Initial Study in Elite Military Servicemembers
Citation: Zanesco, A. P., Denkova, E., Rogers, S. L., MacNulty, W. K., & Jha, A. P. (2018). Mindfulness Training as Cognitive Training in High-Demand Cohorts: An Initial Study in Elite Military Servicemembers. Progress in Brain Research, 244, 323-354. https://doi.org/10.1016/bs.pbr.2018.10.001
Control_Group_Description: No-training control group
Intervention_Description: Mindfulness-Based Attention Training (MBAT) program delivered over 2 weeks (2 sessions per week). Program included concentration exercises, body awareness, open monitoring, and connection exercises.
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Mindfulness-Based Attention Training including concentration exercises, body awareness, open monitoring, and connection exercises
RoB2_Notes: Randomization was at unit level rather than individual level (group-randomized assignment). No blinding of participants or personnel was reported. Missing data was appropriately handled using intention-to-treat analysis with multi-level linear mixed models. Outcome assessors were not blinded, but SART is objective computerized task. Pre-registration (NCT03310112) was mentioned, and all expected outcomes were reported.

Title: Attention control training and transfer effects on cognitive tasks
Citation: Zhang, H., Fan, S., Yang, J., Yi, J., Guan, L., He, H., Zhang, X., Luo, Y., & Guan, Q. (2024). Attention control training and transfer effects on cognitive tasks. Neuropsychologia, 200, 108910. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2024.108910
Control_Group_Description: Sham training with simplified MFT-M task (5:0 arrow congruency and 2000ms exposure time)
Intervention_Description: Backward Masking Majority Function Task (MFT-M) requiring participants to identify the majority direction of arrows within time constraints across 12 cognitive loads varying in information amount and exposure duration
Cognitive_Activity_Description: MFT-M task with 12 blocks per day, 36 trials per block, varying in arrow congruency (5:0, 4:1, 3:2) and exposure time (250, 500, 1000, 2000ms)
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Intervention adherence was 100% with standardized instructions; No missing outcome data (0% attrition); Outcome assessors likely not blinded to group allocation; No pre-registration mentioned but expected outcomes reported
Variance_Conversion_Notes: Control PRE: Converted from SEM=0.900000, N=41; Control POST: Converted from SEM=2.200000, N=41; Intervention PRE: Converted from SEM=0.900000, N=43; Intervention POST: Converted from SEM=2.200000, N=43

Control_Group_Description: Sham training with simplified MFT-M task (5:0 arrow congruency and 2000ms exposure time)
Intervention_Description: Backward Masking Majority Function Task (MFT-M) requiring participants to identify the majority direction of arrows within time constraints across 12 cognitive loads varying in information amount and exposure duration
Cognitive_Activity_Description: MFT-M task with 12 blocks per day, 36 trials per block, varying in arrow congruency (5:0, 4:1, 3:2) and exposure time (250, 500, 1000, 2000ms)
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; Intervention adherence was 100% with standardized instructions; No missing outcome data (0% attrition); Outcome assessors likely not blinded to group allocation; No pre-registration mentioned but expected outcomes reported
Variance_Conversion_Notes: Control PRE: Converted from SEM=0.600000, N=41; Control POST: Converted from SEM=0.600000, N=41; Intervention PRE: Converted from SEM=0.600000, N=43; Intervention POST: Converted from SEM=0.500000, N=43

Title: Improvements in Attention and Cardiac Autonomic Modulation After a 2-Weeks Sprint Interval Training Program: A Fidelity Approach
Citation: de Sousa, A. F. M., Medeiros, A. R., Benitez-Flores, S., Del Rosso, S., Stults-Kolehmainen, M., & Boullosa, D. A. (2018). Improvements in attention and cardiac autonomic modulation after a 2-weeks sprint interval training program: A fidelity approach. Frontiers in Physiology, 9, 241. https://doi.org/10.3389/fphys.2018.00241
Recruitment_Method: Advertisements placed across the university campus
Control_Group_Description: No intervention
Intervention_Description: Sprint interval training (SIT) consisting of 3-4 "all out" sprints of 30s with a load corresponding to 7.5% of body mass, with active rest between sprints
Physical_Activity_Description: 3-4 "all out" sprints of 30s with a load corresponding to 7.5% of body mass, with active rest between sprints
Exercise_Intensity_Reported: Supramaximal all-out sprints, 90% HRmax fidelity criterion
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; No information about blinding of participants or personnel; Complete outcome data with no missing values; Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded; No pre-registration but all expected outcomes reported
Notes_From_File: The protocol document indicates that the minimum age was 18 (Protocol number: 43515415.1.0000.0029); I collapsed the LOW and HIGH fidelity groups into a single group because there was no objective basis for the 90% HRmax criterion. I took the weighted mean and pooled the SD. I did this for age, as well.; the RT and ACC components of the ANT were not valid cognitive tests

Title: No Evidence of Intelligence Improvement After Working Memory Training: A Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Study
Citation: Redick, T. S., Shipstead, Z., Harrison, T. L., Hicks, K. L., Fried, D. E., Hambrick, D. Z., Kane, M. J., & Engle, R. W. (2012). No evidence of intelligence improvement after working memory training: A randomized, placebo-controlled study. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General, 141(3), 359-379. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0029082
Control_Group_Description: Adaptive visual search training
Intervention_Description: Adaptive dual n-back task where subjects responded to visual (location of squares) and auditory (identity of letters) stimuli, with n varying based on performance. Each block presented n+20 trials, and subjects completed 20 blocks in each session.
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Dual n-back task requiring simultaneous processing of visual and auditory stimuli with increasing difficulty based on performance
RoB2_Notes: Randomization process mentioned but specific method not described; 19 subjects (20.6%) dropped out during the study with some imbalance across groups (10 dual n-back, 5 visual search, 4 control); outcome assessors likely blinded to group allocation; all planned outcomes appear to have been reported; no evidence of selective reporting.
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: Intervention duration set to 47 days using conservative approach (upper bound of reported means: 46 days dual n-back, 41 days visual search).

Cognitive_Activity_Description: Dual n-back task requiring simultaneous processing of visual and auditory stimuli with increasing difficulty based on performance
RoB2_Notes: Randomization process mentioned but specific method not described; 19 subjects (20.6%) dropped out during the study with some imbalance across groups (10 dual n-back, 5 visual search, 4 control); outcome assessors likely blinded to group allocation; all planned outcomes appear to have been reported; no evidence of selective reporting.
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: Intervention duration set to 47 days using conservative approach (upper bound of reported means: 46 days dual n-back, 41 days visual search).

Title: Baduanjin Mind-Body Intervention Improves the Executive Control Function
Citation: Chen, T., Yue, G. H., Tian, Y., & Jiang, C. (2017). Baduanjin Mind-Body Intervention Improves the Executive Control Function. Frontiers in Psychology, 7, 2015. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2016.02015
Variable_Name: Interference effect: Incongruent RT - Congruent RT
Control_Group_Description: Progressive muscle relaxation training
Intervention_Description: Baduanjin mind-body exercise consisting of eight movements for limbs, body-trunk, and eye movements
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Mental focus, attention, and self-regulation during exercise
Physical_Activity_Description: Eight movements for limbs, body-trunk, and eye movements
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but method not specified; No missing outcome data reported; No evidence of deviations from intended interventions; Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded; No pre-registration mentioned but expected outcomes reported; No selective reporting evident but no pre-registered protocol available.
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Baduanjin combines physical movements with breathing control and mental focus
Notes_From_File: This is a situation where the author's are CLAIMING that the intervention was cognitive, so I am required by my rules to describe it as both physical and cogntive
Variance_Conversion_Notes: Control PRE: Converted from SEM=6.060000, N=21; Control POST: Converted from SEM=6.490000, N=21; Intervention PRE: Converted from SEM=6.050000, N=21; Intervention POST: Converted from SEM=3.890000, N=21

Title: The effects of 6-weeks program of physical therapeutic exergames on cognitive flexibility focused by reaction times in relation to manual and podal motor abilities
Citation: Badau, D., Badau, A., Joksimovič‡, M., Oancea, B. M., Manescu, C. O., Graur, C., Cornea, G. G., Ene-Voiculescu, V., Cojanu, F., Stefanica, V., Cojocaru, A., Mocanu, G., & Silisteanu, S. C. (2023). The effects of 6-weeks program of physical therapeutic exergames on cognitive flexibility focused by reaction times in relation to manual and podal motor abilities. Balneo and PRM Research Journal, 14(3), 570. https://doi.org/10.12680/balneo.2023.570
Control_Group_Description: Aerobic exercises combined with sports games and athletic exercises
Intervention_Description: Physical therapeutic exergames program using Fitlight Technology (wireless LED spots), exergames through video projection, and interactive whiteboard. The program was designed to improve manual and podal skills, general coordination, spatial orientation, and motor and cognitive reaction speed.
Cognitive_Activity_Description: Exergames requiring rapid identification and response to visual stimuli, involving cognitive flexibility, choice reaction time, and cognitive reaction time
Physical_Activity_Description: 8 physical therapeutic exergames involving manual and podal motor skills, general coordination, and spatial orientation
RoB2_Notes: Randomization mentioned but specific method not described; Full participation in intervention with no reported deviations; No missing data or dropouts reported (100% completion rate); Unclear if outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation; No pre-registration but all expected outcomes reported consistently.
Multimodal_Intervention_Description: Combined physical and cognitive training using exergames that required both physical movements (manual and podal) and cognitive processing (reaction time, decision-making, cognitive flexibility)
Other_Sensitivity_Notes: Pooled from sex-disaggregated data (male + female); avoids pseudoreplication from same study
